Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Situation2: They witness a serious wrongdoing, such as corruption or harm to others, and feel compelled to take decisive moral action.
Story: I was finishing up a trim for Mrs. Patel, one of my favorite regulars, when she glanced in the mirror and smiled. “Could you just take a little more off the fringe?” she asked, her tone gentle as always. I nodded, reaching for my scissors, when I noticed something odd in the reflection—a coworker slipping cash from the register into his pocket. My heart pounded. As a hairdresser, I’m expected to keep my clients happy, to focus on their needs and make sure they leave satisfied. But as a Hindu, I’m taught to stand up for what’s right, to never ignore wrongdoing. My hands trembled slightly as I combed Mrs. Patel’s hair, torn between addressing her request and confronting the theft I’d just witnessed. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my attention, each pulling me in a different direction.
